description: We are walking along the market place right next to the street. The traders sell clothes, fruits, spices, fish (alive or dead) and everything else you can imagine. They are not screaming, only waiting to be asked about their goods and to get a fair price.

Right after getting out of the public bus, we walked towards the district Chinatown. At a quite busy street, there are the first stalls, where they are selling almost only red and golden goods, looking somehow exactly what we have expected from this chinese part of Bangkok. Tourists are trying out drums and bells that are sold at one of the stalls.

On our way to the night market of Hanoi, we cross a stage where some musicians are playing their various instruments. Spectators are standing or sitting on small stools in front of the stage to enjoy the music. We also stop for a moment to listen.

After a long day of travelling with a small and crowded public bus from Hanoi to Halong Bay, we have reached our destination. Now we are sitting in a street kitchen. The owners cook at the entry, while we have our table in the back of the room next to a mattress and a television, which probably belongs to their living area. Quite hungry, we are waiting for our food, while we can see and hear how they prepare it freshly.

Early in the morning we are waiting for the breakfast as well as for some late travel mates in the lobby of our hostel. A boat trip is planned for today. Outside, there are already dozens of motorcycles passing by and honking at each other. As we are still a bit sleepy, they definitely help us to stay awake.

After we have left Halong Bay in a private minivan - which is actually quite cheap because of our group size - our driver asks if he should turn on his music. We agreed, not knowing what awaits us. We now listen to a new interpretation of a christmas song, replayed for the third time as the playlist is repeating itself.

Back in Hanoi, we woke up really early to watch a parade to celebrate the 70th national day of Vietnam. The streets are crowded, citizens holding flags or their mobile phones in their hands, talking to each other and waiting for the parade to cross the point, where we were positioned. A woman voice comes out of a megaphone, announcing something in vietnamese.
We sit in an airplane to the south of Vietnam, Ho-Chi-Minh City. Before departure we listen to the typical instructions on what to do when an emergency occurs - first in Vietnamese, then in English.

To visit the War Remnants Museum was a recommendation of a friend. We were lucky as we just arrived there as it started to rain heavily. The ground floor was partly open so that the rain gets on the floor. Personnel appear to sweep it out. We are standing next to them and to other visitors looking at old war posters of Vietnam.

Close to Ho-Chi-Minh-City, the Cu Chi tunnels, part of an underground system from the Vietnam war, are located. Today it is open for tourists like us. We have joined a tour along the area of the Cu Chi tunnels. We have a short tour break, where we are eating corncobs, wincing whenever we hear other tourist trying out old weapons from the Vietnam war.
It is evening, we are sitting in a small restaurant in Siem Reap, next to our hostel for having dinner. Our table is outside. We are surrounded by other guests, while our food is being prepared.

We are spending a whole day at the temples of Angkor. We began our day with an amazing sunrise. Now it is a few hours later and we are on the way to Ta Prohm, the famous Tomb Raider Temple. We cross musicians sitting at the roadside, playing music to collect some money. On a sign it is said that the band only consists of disabled people. We stop and listen to them.

Now we are on the cambodian island Koh Rong, relaxing at the porch of our Bungalow. There is no electricity during the day, but surprisingly we are not missing it. The weather could be better, it is really windy, but at least it stopped raining. Close to our Bungalow, another one is being repaired by two man.

The second day on Koh Rong. It is evening and we are sitting or lying in a hammock in front of our Bungalow again. The sound of many crickets are filling the air. We are waiting for the rest of our group to get ready for a quite late dinner after a long boat trip during the day

We are in the bus from the coast town Sihanoukville to the capital Phnom Penh. Right before we had some problems to arrive at the bus, because our ferry was late and we missed the previous one. But we are lucky and could transfer our ticket to the following bus and don't have to purchase a new one. Finally in the bus, we can relax and listen to the typical cambodian music in the radio.

We are sitting in a Tuk Tuk driving along the streets of Cambodia's capital Phnom Penh. Our destination is the airport, where we need to catch our flight to Singapore. Our group had to split up on two tuk tuks and now we listen to the various sounds of the traffic, like honks and squeaking breaks.

Standing at the rooftop bar CÉ LA VI on the 57th floor of the Marina Bay Sands Hotel in Singapore to drink our most expensive cocktails (30 Singapore Dollars) so far. To enjoy this incredible view above the roofs of Singapore we put on our best clothes and now listen to the bar keeper working and fellow guest chatting to some electronic music.

Today we spend the day at the botanic gardens of Singapore and explore the surprisingly big garden area. Beside many different kinds of flowers - and especially orchids - there are also greenhouses, rank-covered portals and of course birds and insects. While listening to a call of very prominent crickets we acclimate to the high rate of air moisture in the gardens.

We arrived on Bali by plane just a few hours ago. After finding a well located and cheap hostel in the tourist and lively district Kuta we have decided to spend the evening at the nearby beach. Here we lay down and looking at the stars. While listening to the tide rising we feel the gentle cool breeze on our skin.

After a busy day exploring Kuta and the beaches, we just arrived in our hostel. Previously, we strolled around the streets and have been to a bar for some drinks and listened to some really good life music. Back at our hostel we hear the night sounds of our neighbourhood including the now less noisy traffic.

Today we departed from Kuta and took the bus and after that the ferry to the small Gili islands. After a whole day of traveling we arrived at Gili Trawangan - the biggest of the three islands - and dropped our backpacks off at our bungalows. Right now we are at the beach and recover from the journey while listening to ocean sounds and the local horse-drawn carriages wagons on a pathway nearby as the sun goes down.

One of our daily experiences on Gili Trawangan is the sound of the Muezzin calling the people to prayer before each meal. Our bungalow is quite close to the nearby mosque and therefore we are always witnessing his prayers and songs. Right now we are sitting in front of our bungalows and simultaneously hear the Muezzin and our neighbours working in the backyard.

We have just finished our breakfast at our bungalow which consisted of homemade banana pancakes and fresh fruit shake. Crickets are quite common on Gili, especially in the morning hours. While digesting our breakfast we listen to the calls of our bungalow-cricket.

This morning we made an interesting discovery: in one of the trees at our alley in front of the bungalow lives a bird with a very unique call. The bird doesn't really sound like an animal and rather like some kind of alien spaceship. In addition we can also hear the sounds of a nearby construction site.

For our day we planned a trip to the next big island: Lombok. Here we are hiking through the jungle to the famous waterfall Tiu Kelep. To get there we had to climb the river and its slippy stones. Finally, arrived at Tiu Kelep we now want to take a swim in the cold water and we are already listening to the huge amounts of water falling down from the mountain side.

Today is the birthday of one our group members and we decided to have a relaxed day on the island with renting bikes and spending a lot of time at the beach and in the water. After a opulent breakfast with a self made fruit salad cake we are at the promenade and hear the sounds of bikes passing and ringing and a musician playing the guitar.

A few hours ago we arrived back on Bali from the Gili islands and we've already occupied our rooms. The hotel we chose has a swimming pool, which is located in the atrium of the hotel. At the point of recording we are sitting right in front of the pool next to the fountain after we've enjoyed an evening swim.

We are now in the Sacred Monkey Forest Sanctuary in Ubud. While looking around, we can see monkeys everywhere – from old to newborn monkeys. They play around or search for lice on each other. At the beginning, we were a little bit afraid of them but it turned out that these monkeys are very trusting and climbed on your shoulder, if you give them some banana and nuts to eat.

At the well-known beach Kuta on Bali, surfers can enjoy the waves, which suit perfectly the needs of beginners. We also stop by and rent a board to join other surfers. At the beach there are a lot of activities – people are sunbathing, renting sports equipment or getting a massage. Due to the fact that it is close to the main road, we can also hear traffic noises in the background.

We have a stopover at Surat Thani’s harbour to wait for our ferry that will bring us to our next destiny. As we are all exhausted and hungry from our flight, we eat something for lunch inside the waiting hall. A mixture of sounds is coming from the kitchen, where our meal is being prepared.

We can hear music on every street corner. People are preparing for the famous Full Moon Party on Koh Phangan. There are many tourists coming from all over the world to join the big event. As the name already suggests, the celebration is only when the moon can be seen completely. We are all very excited about the next day.

Today is the day of the Full Moon Party. We are standing in front of our hostel “Sun Cliff Resort”. It seems like it’s the quiet before the storm. Birds are singing dominantly and some motorcycles are passing by. We reflect our trip and notice that we are at the other end of the world - the surrounding, the culture and almost everything is new for us and it seems almost surreal being here. However, we enjoy every moment of it.

The day after the Full Moon Party is very quiet. People are resting after such a big party. However, on the streets, we can hear the intense humming of the power pole and some cars passing by. The power can be heard pole so clearly and dominantly because the cables are just three meters above our heads.

Right now we are inside of a 7-Eleven shop on Koh Tao. Especially in Thailand it is a widespread supermarket chain, is located on the island Koh Tao. The significant doorbell, which can be heard clearly, is ringing every time, when someone is entering or leaving the convenient shop. It always awakes old memories because on many days we went to one of the 7-Elevens to buy cheap drinks and delicious sandwiches

The sound of the beach on Koh Tao is wonderful. The waves approach the beach rhythmically and the scenery is silent and peaceful. It is easy to lose track of time while standing at the beach and looking at the ocean and the sunset.

We are at the harbour of Koh Tao now. It is time to move on and to get ready for new adventures. We can hear the singing of birds close to the pier and also of a starting engine. Although there are many boats driving from one place to another, the water is crystal clear and blue. It seems like the ocean refuses to get polluted by the traffic caused by the tourism.

Right now we are travelling with the night ferry from Koh Tao to Surat Thani. The loud machine noises keep some of us awake for quite some time. Nevertheless, we are all getting sleepy after a while because the days before were exciting but also exhausting. With the sounds of the engine in the background and the swinging of the boat, we fall asleep.

We are sitting at the beach of Koh Phi Phi. We hear a lot of different activities: people talking loudly, music are played in restaurants and engine noises of approaching and departing boats are audible. Due to the fact that it is very warm, we sunbathe and enjoy the view on the mountains.

To have an eternal souvenir, one of us is getting a tattoo. The tattoo studio on Koh Phi Phi plays some loud music – maybe to calm people down and to ease the atmosphere. We are pleased with the result and every time looking at the ink under the skin, it will evoke our memories from the trip.

An hour ago we arrived at our last destination before flying back home: Bangkok. With a taxi, we drive from the airport to the city center, where our hostel is located. The radio can be heard in the background. It happened quite often that taxi drivers play their own music - usually unknown to us - while driving.

Wat Pho is a temple complex that is mainly known for its big lying Buddha statue. We are inside the big hall of the golden Buddha that almost fills up the whole room. The sound we hear, besides from people whispering, is the dropping of coins into 108 prayer bowls. The metal bowls are located behind the back of the Buddha and whenever someone drops some coins into each single bowl, it is meant to bring this person luck.

Two days before our flight back home we decided to do a surprise visit to our friend who is spending his semester abroad in Bangkok. He is studying at the SOA_D university in the south of the city. Before his photography class, which we wanted to take by surprise, we get some lunch in the cafeteria of the university. Here we listen to the typical sounds of a cafeteria and of students getting and eating their meals.

At our last evening in Bangkok and also Thailand we need to fulfill some last shopping duties. In the district Silom - the same where our hostel is located - there is a well-known night market. Merchants offer their goods here, from elephant statues over harem pants to fake Nike shoes. The sounds are as diverse as the offers: busy people chatting, market preparations and music from nearby night clubs.

Today is the day of our departure back home and we are standing in front of our hostel for the last time. After six weeks of travelling, experiencing so many unforgettable memories and meeting a lot of new people, it feels weird to think about leaving all of this and return home. Standing at the sidewalk with our ready backpacks we listen to the traffic noise, which is very distinctive in Bangkok and differs so much from Germany. Almost all of our visited countries have one thing in common: the traffic rules are totally different. We remember how odd the traffic system seemed to us when we arrived here in the beginning. We have to be extra carefully before crossing a road, getting used to the left-hand traffic and even being afraid to be involved in car accident. Nevertheless we are going to miss this, the things we experienced and Southeast Asia in general. But we are definitely coming back.
